discussion.content:
The printer must be connected to the same wireless network as the user, not the guest network. Guest networks are isolated from the main network.
It is unnecessary for the user's computer to act as a print server.
IPP is a standard printing protocol; almost every modern printer uses it already.
The user does not require DHCP on their computer.

Although the question doesn't clearly state that the printer was intended for use on the company network instead of the guest network, the available answer choices boil down to assuming that was the case.
Not A - the user's computer is in the office - guests could not reach the office network
Not B - IPP is a Microsoft printing protocol - can't assume the user's box is Microsoft
Not C - The problem is with the printer not the computer
D - most correct answer by default

questions.question_text:
A user purchases a wireless printer and sets it up in an office. The user installs all necessary software for the printer on the computer and connects the printer to the guest wireless network. However, when the user attempts to print to the printer, nothing happens.
Which of the following will resolve the issue?

choices.B: Configure the printer to use the Internet printing protocol.
choices.C: Ensure the user's computer is set to DHCP.
choices.A: Set up the user's computer to act as a print server.
choices.D: Connect the printer to the company wireless network.

discussion.content: Definitely, A guy's no way CMOS bat can cause the system to reboot as mentioned in the question!

comments.content: A is correct. Bad sectors will cause reboots. I thought it was C, but that would just cause the computer to shut down, not reboot.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Has to be A
A or C, but not a CMOS-Battery

The issue could be a bunch of different things, why can't we wait until the hardware monitoring device is completed?
I'm not sure but if I had to choose, I would go with A...
It could be Ram or harddrive or overheating. Need to have a better question.

Bad CMOS battry will cause unsaved bios settings so you may not get the right boot order or boot mode (Legacy / UEFI ) and beacuse of that computer may not boot and time and date would be somthing like 2012/01/01

questions.question_text: A technician needs to determine why a PC reboots after a short period of use. The technician installs a hardware monitoring application as part of the troubleshooting process. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?
Multiple independent software developers share the same cloud infrastructure for hosting their healthcare applications. Which of the following cloud types BEST describes the model in use?

discussion.content: A community cloud is a multi-tenant platform which allows several companies work on the same platform, given that they have similar needs and concerns.
Must be B.. 2.4Ghz is known for interference and can travel further than 5Ghz
It's B.

Selected Answer: B
The advantage of 5 GHz is that it has a higher transfer speed and it's less vulnerable to interference. But at the same time, it does have a shorter range.

A 2.4 GHz connection travels farther at lower speeds, while 5 GHz frequencies provide faster speeds at shorter range
so, the answer should be 5 GHZ

Selected Answer: B
5ghz has less interference

Selected Answer: B
5ghz has smaller ranges and less interference so i dont get it why people said it's 2.4 GHz. 802.11n has 2.4 and 5ghz

Selected Answer: B
Answer (B)
802.11n can have both 2.4 and 5 GHz 
but the word key in the question is "Small range".
2.4GHz band offers coverage at a longer range

comments.content: 802.11n can have either or both 2.4 and 5.

discussion.content: Keyword is 802.11n. Has to be A. If it's 802.11ac then it's B.

questions.question_text: Which of the following frequencies is used to provide 802.11n wireless connectivity in smaller ranges with less probability of interference?
Which of the following devices is susceptible to broadcast storms if configured incorrectly?

discussion.content:
correct answer is C. check broadcast storm on:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcast_storm#Causes

comments.content: Correct, C is the correct answer. Look up STP and how that is implemented in Layer 2 switches. Routers use TTL (time to live) when they send messages, layer 2 switches do not.

discussion.content: Its C. To avoid broadcast storm, the switches uses Spanning Tree Protocol.
to avoid broadcaststorms use Shortest Path Bridging or Spanning Tree Protocol

Selected Answer: C
Most commonly the cause is a switching loop in the Ethernet network topology (i.e. two or more paths exist between switches). As broadcasts and multicasts are forwarded by switches out of every port, the switch or switches will repeatedly rebroadcast broadcast messages and flood the network. Since the layer-2 header does not support a time to live (TTL) value, if a frame is sent into a looped topology, it can loop forever.
-Wikipedia link

C. Switch. These are caused over VLANS which is layer 2 on a managed switch.
Professor Messer covers this in a 2015 video

Selected Answer: C
Switches cause these
